snippet: An examination of the strike Wednesday at a U.N. shelter in Gaza suggests that Israeli troops paid little heed to warnings to safeguard such sites and may have used heavy artillery not designed for precision use.
abstract: Examination of Israeli strike that killed 21 people at United Nations school sheltering displaced Palestinians suggests that Israeli troops paid little heed to warnings to safeguard such sites and may have used weapons inappropriate for urban areas despite rising alarm over civilian deaths; strike renews questions about tactics Israel uses in dense neighborhood and especially near shelters.

byline.original: By BEN HUBBARD and JODI RUDOREN
byline.contributor: Ben Hubbard reported from Jabaliya, and Jodi Rudoren from Jerusalem. Fares Akram contributed reporting from Gaza.

lead_paragraph: An examination of the strike Wednesday at a U.N. shelter in Gaza suggests that Israeli troops paid little heed to warnings to safeguard such sites and may have used heavy artillery not designed for precision use.

headline.main: Questions of Weapons and Warnings in Past Barrage on a Gaza Shelter
headline.print_headline: Questions of Weapons and Warnings in Past Barrage on a Shelter
